myEngine

Class Actor

  • java.lang.Object
    • javafx.scene.Node
      • javafx.scene.image.ImageView
        • myEngine.Actor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget

    public abstract class Actor
extends javafx.scene.image.ImageView
    Actor is an abstract base class for general sprites in an arcade style game. Because Actor extends ImageView, you have access to all the ImageView commands such as: 
      - getX(), getY(), setX(), setY()
  - setImage()
  - getFitHeight(), getFitWidth()

    • Constructor Detail

      • Actor

        public Actor()

    • Method Detail

      • move

        public void move(double dx,
                 double dy)
        Moves this actor by the given dx and dy.
        Parameters:
        dx - the amount to move horizontally (change in x)
        dy - the amount to move vertically (change in y)

      • getWorld

        public World getWorld()
        Returns the World this actor is in, or null if it is not in a world. Remember that World is a subclass of Pane and in JavaFX, a Pane keeps track of all its child Nodes for you. Therefore, to get the World an Actor is in, use the Pane method getParent() and cast it into a World.
        Returns:
        the World this actor is in, or null if it is not in a world

      • getWidth

        public double getWidth()
        Returns The width of the current image of this actor. Doing this will take two steps. First you have to get the Bounds of the ImageView (Actor) and then you have to ask the Bounds object for its width.
        Returns:
        the width of the current image of this actor, taking into account any transformations.

      • getHeight

        public double getHeight()
        Returns The height of the current image of this actor. Requires the same steps as getWidth().
        Returns:
        the height of the current image of this actor, taking into account any transformations.

      • getIntersectingObjects

        public <A extends Actor> java.util.List<A> getIntersectingObjects(java.lang.Class<A> cls)
        Returns a list of the actors of a given type intersecting this actor. Implementation directions: The method header is given to you already so just copy it as is. What you need to do is to first make some kind of List (for example: ArrayList) of type A objects. Then iterate through that list and if all of the following conditions are met, then add the Actor to the list and return the list after the loop is finished. 
        Conditions for being added to the list:
        - The object isn't yourself ('this' object)
  - The object's Class type matches the method parameter's Class type
  - The object intersects you ('this' object)
        Note: An Actor is a Node and Node already has intersection handling via its intersects() method. Look it up in the Node API.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the class of intersecting actors that will be in the returned list
        Parameters:
        cls - The type of intersecting actors that should be in the list
        Returns:
        a list of all actors of the given type intersecting this actor

      • getOneIntersectingObject

        public <A extends Actor> A getOneIntersectingObject(java.lang.Class<A> cls)
        Returns one actor of the given class that is intersecting this actor. The implementation is the same as the previous method except that instead of building a List of all intersecting Actors just return the first one that qualifies.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the class of intersecting actor that will be in the returned
        Parameters:
        cls - the type of actor to return
        Returns:
        an intersecting actor of the given class, or null if no such actor

      • act

        public abstract void act(long now)
        This method is called every frame once start has been called on the world.
        Parameters:
        now - the current time in nanoseconds.
